text.strong: ‌What language do you speak at home most of the time?‌

text.strong: ‌Which languages do the people you live with speak at home?‌
‌Think of the language spoken in your home that you understand best, apart from <PISA reading test language>.‌
‌How confident do you feel about your ability to do the following activities in this language?‌

text.em: ‌(If you never do some of the activities below, please try to imagine a situation in which you had to try doing them.)‌
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Understand what people say to each other
Understand the <dialogues> in a video (e.g. TV programmes, movies)
Ask for practical information (e.g. directions to or time and place of a festival)
Read about an event (e.g. a festival or a sport match) from a website or newspaper
Write a message (e.g. chat, email or letter) to friends or family
Write a note to tell someone that you will be away from home for a few hours

text.em: ‌(<Enrichment lessons> refer to any lessons you followed in addition to regular lessons because you are interested in further learning. <Remedial lessons> refer to any lessons you followed in addition to regular lessons to meet your school’s <English¹> learning goals.)‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Collaborate with students from another school in <English²>
<English²> language clubs (e.g. debating or reading club)
<English²> language competitions (e.g. for writing or debating)
Communicating in <English²> with students from abroad (e.g. through mail, email, instant messaging or video calls)
Excursions or field trips related to <English²> learning
Communicating in <English²> with students from abroad visiting your school
Conversations in <English²> with other students outside the class
Listening to guests invited by the school to speak to students in <English²>

text.strong: ‌In your <English¹> lessons, how often do you do the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I listen to <English²> (e.g. songs, listening exercises, podcasts).
I watch videos in <English²> (e.g. short video clips, tv series, movies).
I talk with other students in <English²>.
I speak <English²> in front of the class.
I work in groups of three or more students in <English²>.
I read something in <English²> (e.g. articles from newspapers or websites).
I write a text in <English²> (e.g. for a letter or email).

text.strong: ‌In your <English¹> lessons, how often do you do the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I repeat an <English²> word or phrase to improve my pronunciation.
I learn a list of <English²> words or phrases.
I learn how to be polite in <English²>.
I write sentences that my teacher reads or plays from an audio recording (dictation).
I imitate the pronunciation of an <English²> word or phrase.
I listen to an explanation of an <English²> grammar rule.
I learn the correct word order in <English²> sentences and questions.
I learn how to conjugate verbs (e.g. I go - she goes; go - went - gone).

Give suggestions in <PISA reading test language> or another language different from <English²> on how to improve speaking and writing.
Explain in <English²> what you should do.
Explain in <PISA reading test language> or another language different from <English²>what you should do.

‌About once every two or three months‌

label.text: Give me feedback on my strengths
Tell students which areas to improve on
Discuss with me an action plan to improve my learning
Ask students to give feedback on each other’s work
Ask me to evaluate my own performance
Ask me to set my own learning goals
Discuss with me the progress I have made in <English²>
Provide feedback on how to improve my <English²> proficiency

text.strong: ‌In your <English¹> lessons, how often does your teacher assess learning in the following ways?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
‌Once or twice during the school year‌
‌About once every two or three months‌

label.text: By administering vocabulary assignments (e.g. quizzes or exercises)
By administering grammar assignments (e.g. quizzes or exercises)
By interacting with students in <English²> to assess their oral communication skills
By evaluating texts written by students in <English²> (e.g. short stories, essays)
By asking questions about what is written in an <English²> text
By evaluating a presentation given by students in <English²>
By listening to conversations between students in <English²> to assess their communication skills
By administering listening comprehension exercises (e.g. multiple choice or open questions)
By asking students to pronounce words or sentences in <English²> to evaluate their pronunciation

text.strong: ‌In your opinion, how important is it to know <English²> for the following purposes?‌

For using computers and other technical devices

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements on learning <English²>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: An insufficient level of <English²> will compromise my future career.
I have to improve my <English²> because otherwise I will have to forgo the lifestyle I want.
I will disappoint those who are important to me if I fail to master the <English²> language.
I will have fewer career opportunities in the future if I don’t master the <English²> language.
I want to improve my <English²> to keep my teachers’ respect.
My parents would be disappointed if I stopped learning <English²>.
My friends will like me less if I don’t improve my <English²>.

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

I get nervous when I have to speak <English²>
I get nervous when I am listening to someone speaking <English²>.
I get nervous when trying to understand a text in <English²>.
I get tense when I have to write in <English²>.
I worry that my <English²> pronunciation is wrong.
I worry that I use the wrong words when speaking <English²>.
<English¹> is an interesting subject to learn.

text.strong: ‌Think of your current <English¹> teacher. How many school semesters did you receive <English¹> lessons with this teacher?‌
‌How many school semesters did you receive <English¹> lessons?‌
‌In your <English¹> lessons this school year, how often do the following activities happen?‌

label.text: My teacher points out a similarity or difference between <English²> and another language.
My teacher encourages me to compare <English²> with a language I know well.
My teacher gives instructions in both <English²> and <PISA reading test language>.
My teacher gives instructions in both <English²> and another language apart from <PISA reading test language>.
My teacher encourages me to use other languages I know to help me learn <English²>.

My teacher encourages me to use another language I know well to prepare a task for the <English¹> lesson, e.g. pre-writing a text in a language of our choice, doing research for a presentation in another language.
My teacher encourages me to keep or update a language portfolio (e.g. <European Language Portfolio>) for <English²>.
My teacher encourages me to keep or update a language portfolio (e.g. <European Language Portfolio>) for other languages apart from <English²> I know well (e.g. <PISA reading test language>).
My teacher encourages me to use digital tools for translation or bilingual dictionaries.
